text:
INTERVIEWER: So when you
think about the expansion

into these, DRC, South
Sudan, talk to me

about the most
difficult part of that,

practically in the
last few years.
What have you experienced?

What part of the model
has been most stressed?

MWANGI: The most stressed
is infrastructure,

in a sense that banking
infrastructure in modern days
require a lot of modern tools.

It's carried on
very evolved system.
So it's all computerized.
And then you're going to DRC.

And you find everywhere,
you have to put a generator.

It requires a huge investment
in telecommunication.
It forces you to use satellites.
And that I would call it a big--

security is another
big challenge.
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

You would imagine that
providing your own security

in such a massive
country as the DRC,

providing your own
electricity, providing--

so you are telecom
infrastructure.
That I would say is--

but the most expensive
[INAUDIBLE] I've seen

is where there is a
[? lapse ?] in terms of peace.

The situation in
South Sudan got us

one of the best
subsidiaries we had in 2013,

melted down to almost
nothing because everybody
escaped from the country.

And it became more from
a commercial enterprise

to what one would call dealing
with philanthropy and economy.
So that extreme swings--
and peace becomes huge.

And then lastly is the issue
of policy and regulation.

You'll find every country seems
to be at a different level

in development of regulatory
policies and legal framework,

rather than leader
created, there

are difficulties
that while you have

a single instant
centralized system, when

it comes to execution,
you have to break

that down to tie with the
policies and regulations
within the country.

Those three, I would say
are the major bottlenecks.
